articles.headline: Aiming to Keep Pace, Chrysler Is Shrinking S.U.V.'s
articles.snippet: Chrysler plans to spend $1.8 billion retooling a Detroit factory that builds Jeeps so that it can start making a more fuel-efficient, car-based crossover vehicle there.
articles.abstract: Chrysler plans to spend $1.8 billion retooling a Detroit factory that builds Jeeps so that it can start making a more fuel-efficient, car-based crossover vehicle there.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich. — In the latest sign of the burial of the era of the S.U.V., Chrysler announced Wednesday that it would spend $1.8 billion to convert a Detroit automotive plant from producing traditional Jeep Grand Cherokees to making more fuel-efficient, car-based crossovers.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Your Photos, Off the Shelf at Last
articles.snippet: A company offers to scan 1,000 photos the same day they are received, for $50. What’s the catch?
articles.abstract: A company offers to scan 1,000 photos the same day they are received, for $50. What’s the catch?
articles.lead_paragraph: A recipe for Toxic Photo Soup: Layer 1,000 photos in a large, watertight plastic storage tub. Place high on basement shelving unit. Fail to notice small, leaky basement window nearby. Marinate, unattended, three to four years. Open and serve.

articles.headline: Insurgency’s Scars Line Afghanistan’s Main Road
articles.snippet: A highway that was once the showpiece of the United States reconstruction effort is now a dangerous gantlet of mines and attacks.
articles.abstract: A highway that was once the showpiece of the United States reconstruction effort is now a dangerous gantlet of mines and attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAYDEBAD, Afghanistan  Not far from here, just off the highway that was once the showpiece of the United States reconstruction effort in Afghanistan, three American soldiers and their Afghan interpreter were ambushed and killed seven weeks ago.

articles.headline: Caution Pays for a Lender in New Jersey
articles.snippet: A bank that flew under the radar screen has quietly racked up a market value of $10 billion, eclipsing troubled giants that have been swamped by mortgage and credit card losses.
articles.abstract: A bank that flew under the radar screen has quietly racked up a market value of $10 billion, eclipsing troubled giants that have been swamped by mortgage and credit card losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARAMUS, N.J.  Ronald E. Hermance Jr. is something of an oddity these days. He is a banker who has not been battered by the credit crisis.

articles.headline: Woman to Woman, Online
articles.snippet: The rapid growth in advertising and traffic to Web sites aimed primarily at women has attracted the attention of major media companies.
articles.abstract: The rapid growth in advertising and traffic to Web sites aimed primarily at women has attracted the attention of major media companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Heather Armstrong’s wickedly funny blog about motherhood, Dooce, is more than just an outlet for the creativity and frustrations of a modern mother. The site, chock full of advertising, is a moneymaking machine — so much so that Ms. Armstrong and her husband have both quit their regular jobs.

articles.headline: G.O.P. in House at Risk in Northeast
articles.snippet: Across the Northeast, Republicans are in danger of losing half a dozen or more Congressional seats in November.
articles.abstract: Across the Northeast, Republicans are in danger of losing half a dozen or more Congressional seats in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Across the increasingly Democratic Northeast, Republicans are in danger of losing half a dozen or more Congressional seats in November, as even districts once considered safe have become vulnerable to well-financed Democrats, according to political analysts and members of both parties.

articles.headline: Peace Plan Offers Russia a Rationale to Advance
articles.snippet: A deal brokered by France not only failed to slow the Russian advance in Georgia, but also allowed Russia to claim that it could push even deeper.
articles.abstract: A deal brokered by France not only failed to slow the Russian advance in Georgia, but also allowed Russia to claim that it could push even deeper.
articles.lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia  It was nearly 2 a.m. on Wednesday when President Nicolas Sarkozy of France announced he had accomplished what seemed virtually impossible: Persuading the leaders of Georgia and Russia to agree to a set of principles that would stop the war.

articles.headline: Back-to-School Discounts Are Deeper, More Creative
articles.snippet: Thrift is the theme this back-to-school year, and stores are trying to play to the public mood with deeper and more creative discounts.
articles.abstract: Thrift is the theme this back-to-school year, and stores are trying to play to the public mood with deeper and more creative discounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Parents shopping for back-to-school gear could be forgiven for walking into a store nowadays and thinking they have gone through a time warp.

articles.headline: Living Costs Rising Fast, and Wages Are Trailing
articles.snippet: The cost of living is rising at the fastest rate since the recession of the early 1990s, handing a de facto pay cut to the American worker.
articles.abstract: The cost of living is rising at the fastest rate since the recession of the early 1990s, handing a de facto pay cut to the American worker.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cost of living, led by the soaring cost of gasoline and food, is rising at the fastest rate since the recession of the early 1990s, the government said on Thursday, handing a de facto pay cut to the American worker.

articles.headline: Musharraf Set to Resign in Days, Officials Assert
articles.snippet: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan is expected to quit rather than face impeachment, Pakistani politicians said.
articles.abstract: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan is expected to quit rather than face impeachment, Pakistani politicians said.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Faced with desertions by his political supporters and the unsettling neutrality of the Pakistani military, President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan is expected to resign in the next few days rather than face impeachment, Pakistani politicians and Western diplomats said Thursday.
